timeline.subject: Jean Callerey
timeline.details: Jean denied all charges, acknowledged his parents' execution and his reputation

timeline.subject: Jean Callerey
timeline.details: Confronted with witnesses; made no reproaches; denied all charges

timeline.subject: Jean Callerey
timeline.details: Procureur d'office asked for question ordinaire

timeline.subject: Jean Callerey
timeline.details: Confessed as soon as he felt thumbscrews; gave detailed confession

timeline.subject: Jean Callerey
timeline.details: Confirmed all confessions made under torture

timeline.subject: Jean Callerey
timeline.details: Again confirmed confessions; added details about sabbat hierarchy and his children

timeline.subject: Jean Callerey

timeline.subject: Jean Callerey

accomplices_named.name: Catherine veuve Jean Grand George
accomplices_named.context: seen at several sabbats; transformed into wolf with Jean to kill a cow

accomplices_named.name: Nicolas fils Vincent Bandesapt
accomplices_named.context: seen at sabbat; taken there by his mother Laurence

prior_accusations.context: denounced Jean; she was convicted in 1611

notable_quotes.speaker: Nicolas Bandesapt
notable_quotes.french: qu'il luy feroit despendre son bien sans qu'il se donne de garde
notable_quotes.english: that he would make him spend his wealth without him being aware

notable_quotes.speaker: Nicolas Bandesapt
notable_quotes.french: qu'il se debvoit bien contanter de l'avoir sy longtemps faict languir
notable_quotes.english: that he should be content to have made him languish so long

notable_quotes.speaker: Marguitte femme Vincent Bandesapt
notable_quotes.french: aymeroit mieulx despendre son bien pour le faire brusler que de le despendre languisant mallade comme il faisoit
notable_quotes.english: would prefer to spend his wealth to have him burned than to spend it languishing sick as he was doing
notable_quotes.context: witnessed Nicolas's determination to prosecute Jean

notable_quotes.speaker: Jean Grand George (dying words via Catherine)
notable_quotes.french: et dit que puisqu'il luy convenoit mourir cela ne luy serviroit de rien, et que peult estre ledit prevenu luy causeroit encor quelques autres desplaisir
notable_quotes.english: and said that since he had to die it would serve him no purpose, and that perhaps the accused would cause him yet other displeasure
notable_quotes.context: deciding not to confront Jean before death

notable_quotes.speaker: Jean Callerey
notable_quotes.french: qu'il failloit donner ung rabasjoye audit Bandesapt, et qu'il estoit desja tousjours ung des plus brave au sabat a la dance et l'ung des premiers
notable_quotes.english: that it was necessary to give a comedown to Bandesapt, and that he was always one of the bravest at the sabbat in the dance and one of the first
notable_quotes.context: confession about making Nicolas Bandesapt ill after the sword incident

notable_quotes.speaker: Jean Callerey
notable_quotes.french: ou il y avoit heu grand peine, et estoit en grande fascherie ad cause de sa pauvreté et enduroit grande famine
notable_quotes.english: where he had great hardship, and was in great distress because of his poverty and endured great hunger
notable_quotes.context: describing circumstances of his seduction by the devil

notable_quotes.speaker: Jean Callerey
notable_quotes.french: qu'il estoit pauvrement trompé et abbusé
notable_quotes.english: that he was poorly deceived and abused
notable_quotes.context: realizing devil's promises were false when gold turned to sand

notable_quotes.speaker: Jean Callerey
notable_quotes.french: tant avoit il regret d'estre ainsy tanté et abbusé du diable
notable_quotes.english: so much did he regret being thus tempted and abused by the devil
notable_quotes.context: explaining why he resolved to confess promptly

relationships.evidence_text: when he married a woman from the village nearly 6 years before
his parents had been executed for witchcraft
his parents had been executed for witchcraft
his brother (now named as Valentin) being a witch
widow of Jean Grand George his neighbour
taken by his mother Laurence, executed 3 years earlier
they had done some work together - were both carpenters

economic_context.details: Jean was a poor carpenter who experienced extreme poverty and hunger. Multiple disputes arose over: (1) quality of wood supplied to him for carpentry work; (2) money owed for work done with fellow carpenter; (3) land lease Jean wanted but Jean Grand George secured; (4) damage caused by Jean's geese to Mr. d'Estival's oat field; (5) damage caused by Jean Grand George's pigs to Jean's field; (6) roof tiles dispute with Nicolas Bandesapt. Jean's poverty was explicitly mentioned as context for his seduction by the devil, and his confession shows concern for leaving his two children destitute.

harms_catalog.harm_description: became very ill, bedridden for 3 or 4 months, recovered after confronting Jean
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: quarrelled and fought with fists over roof tiles; Jean threatened him
harms_catalog.method_alleged: witchcraft (unspecified in testimony, confession says devil offered to make him ill with powder)

harms_catalog.harm_description: took to bed, died in 6 days
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Jean Grand George secured land lease from Mr. d'Estival that Jean wanted

harms_catalog.harm_description: felt illness as he passed Jean's manure heap, took to bed Sunday, died Friday
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: damage pigs had done to Jean's field
harms_catalog.method_alleged: felt illness near manure heap (confession: devil sprinkled powder on him)

harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Jean complained Mongeay gave him difficult wood to work with, made threats

harms_catalog.victim_name: young cow belonging to Thieriot Barbonnille
harms_catalog.harm_description: died suddenly after passing in front of Jean's house
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: dispute over money Jean demanded for carpentry work done together

harms_catalog.harm_description: mysteriously strangled in the middle of the herd
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Jean's old cow got lost before he arrived to accompany it; Jean was very angry and made threats
harms_catalog.method_alleged: witchcraft (confession: devil transformed into wolf to strangle cow)

harms_catalog.harm_description: painful fall at door of his house on New Year's Day
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Nicolas killed 3 or 4 of Jean's geese on orders from Mr. d'Estival for damaging oat field
harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: previous harvest to New Year's Day (several months)

harms_catalog.harm_description: immediately died when he tested black powder on them
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: none - testing powder given by devil

harms_catalog.victim_name: cow belonging to Jean Florentin of St. Remy
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Jean Florentin would not sell him oats
Mr. d'Estival did not give him as much work as his companions
Jean Clerc called him 'fils de sorcier' (son of witch)

harms_catalog.harm_description: killed by Jean and Catherine when transformed into wolves; taken to sabbat
harms_catalog.attributed_to: Jean Callerey and Catherine veuve Jean Grand George (confession)
harms_catalog.method_alleged: transformation into wolves using grease and skins with big teeth

extraction_metadata.notes: Complete 5-page trial document with clear procedural timeline. Jean Callerey confessed under torture (thumbscrews) and maintained confession through multiple interrogations. Trial shows typical pattern of neighbor conflicts over economic matters (land, animals, work) escalating to witchcraft accusations. Jean's extreme poverty explicitly mentioned as context for devil's seduction. Both parents previously executed; brother fled similar accusations. Named accomplices including primary accuser Catherine. Executed within 16 days of initial testimony.
